titleInfo.title: Tuning the Magnetic Properties of Fe3Se4 as an Alternative Permanent Magnet

mods:mods.abstract: The need for cheaper, stronger permanent magnets is becoming more vital, as clean-energy technologies and commercial electronics rely heavily on Nd₂Fe₁₄B and SmCo₅ for energy conversion. The Nd and Sm metals, however, are expensive rare-earth elements with highly concentrated production that poses a risk of a supply chain disruption, thus increasing vulnerability of the U.S. economy. Extensive research efforts have been focused on both developing rare-earth free permanent magnets and tuning the magnetic properties of known materials to reduce the total amount of rare-earth needed. Such tuning has been well studied in bulk materials, but on the nanoscale, there remains many avenues for further exploration and discoveries. In Chapter One, the background information is addressed and using prior literature, a research hypothesis is predicated. Understanding the currently known permanent magnet materials allows a target material to be chosen, which will be subjected to modification of its magnetic properties in the bulk and nanoscale forms. More specifically, this thesis focuses on the ferrimagnetic material Fe3Se4. In Chapter Two, the synthesis methods to obtain the chosen materials and the characterization methods used to study the behavior of these materials is described. In Chapter Three, an in-depth study of the formation of nanoscale Fe3Se4 by applying various synthetic conditions is described. It is demonstrated that using molecular precursors as both Fe and Se sources subdues the formation of Fe₇Se₈ impurity observed in previous works on the synthesis of Fe₃Se₄ nanoparticles. The most significant distinction of this synthetic pathway is the observation of the conversion of FeSe to Fe3Se¬4 through anion diffusion, in contrast to the cation diffusion mechanism reported in the literature. In Chapter Four, tuning the magnetic properties of Fe₃Se₄ by doping 3d transition metal ions for Fe is investigated. Fe₃Se₄ has distinct octahedrally coordinated high-spin Fe2+ and Fe3+ sites. An attempt to target the Fe site substitution by changing the oxidation state of the dopant precursor is made. The impact of doping on the structural and magnetic properties of Fe₃Se₄ characterized by X-ray, Raman, and magnetic measurements are described. In Chapter Five, the focus shifts to an in-depth investigation into the (Fe₁₋ᵪCuᵪ)₃Se₄ series. The effects of Cu substitution on structural and magnetic properties in both the nanoscale and bulk materials are addressed. An attempt to elucidate the nature of the Cu dopant and the cause of the large observed increase in the magnetic hardness is made. The structural and magnetic properties of the Cu-substituted Fe₃Se₄ have been characterized by X-ray, Raman, and magnetic measurements.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Michael Shatruk, Professor Directing Dissertation; Peng Xiong, University Representative; Geoffrey F. Strouse, Committee Member; Joseph Schlenoff, Committee Member.
